I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  for  the  Bridge  Replacement  for  Improved  Rural  Access  Sector 
Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Major Bridges Study, 
and if the Board approves the proposed loans, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by 
the Board, will approve the TA.1
 
 
The  project  will  improve  PNG’s  two-lane  national  road  network  by  replacing  narrow 
2. 
temporary  modular  steel  (or  Bailey)  and  other  deteriorated  bridges  with  permanent  two-lane 
structures. The reusable Bailey bridges will be reassembled on rural roads to improve access. 
The project is the first phase of the proposed bridge replacement program and covers five of the 
16  priority  national  roads.  It  is  envisaged  that  the  project  scope  will  be  expanded  in  future  to 
finance  subsequent  phases  of  the  bridge  replacement  program.  The  project  will  develop  the 
capacity  of  the  Department  of  Works  (DOW)  bridge  asset  management  system  (BAMS)  and 
improve  road  safety  awareness  in  rural  areas  of  PNG  where  the  accident  rate  is  high.  The 
project  preparatory  work  was  undertaken  through  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  financed 
TA.2
 

     

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
The  6.6  million  population  of  PNG  spread  over  a  land  area  of  about  462,000  square 
3. 
kilometers (km2
) is connected by a network of 8,500 km of national roads and over 20,000 km of 
provincial  and  district  roads.  The  bulk  of  the  population  (87%)  lives  in  rural  areas.  The  road 
network on the mainland is not fully integrated because of rugged mountains, major rivers, and 
rainforests—requiring  air  and  marine  transport  to  access  unconnected  areas.  Similarly,  the 
islands  are  connected  by  air  and  shipping  lines.  However,  most  of  the  population  depends  on 
road transport for its economic activities and basic social services.   
 
4. 
Owing  to  the  rugged  terrain  and  geographic  and  climatic  conditions,  PNG  has  a 
relatively large number of bridges for the size of its road network. It is estimated that there are 
over  700  bridges  on  the  national  road  network. 3  A  large  proportion  of  these  are  single-lane 
Bailey  bridges4  that  were  used  because  of  their  low  cost  and  faster  deployment  during  early 
stages  of  development  of  the  national  road  network.  However,  limited  load  carrying  capacity, 
increasing traffic volume, and deterioration over time have made the Bailey bridges a safety risk 
and weak link in the two-lane national road system. Although the government, with the support 
of  development  partners,  is  actively  improving  and  upgrading  the  roads,  there  has  not  been 
much investment for improvement of bridges. In view of the large number of bridges involved, a 
long-term  program  is  needed  to  replace  the  Bailey  and  other  deteriorated  bridges  gradually—
starting with the 16 priority national roads.5
  
 
5. 
The  project  offers  a comprehensive  bridge replacement  program.  A  sector  approach  is 
adopted  to  strengthen  the  support  for  the  government’s  policies  for  development  of  the  road 

                                                
1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Preparing the Bridge Replacement for Improved Rural 

Access Project. Manila (TA 7594-PNG).  

3 From DOW’s BAMS database. The estimate does not include culverts and other minor structures. 
4 Bailey bridges were originally developed for providing temporary crossing in case of emergencies such as natural 

5 See  the  National  Transport Development  Plan, 2006–2010.  The  16  roads  provide  the main  arterial system  of  the 

disasters and military use.   

country.    

 2 

 

   

subsector  and  to  provide  flexibility  in  implementation.  Detailed  selection  criteria  have  been 
developed to assign priority to bridges that are to be replaced. Based on available financing and 
ease  of contract  packaging,  bridges  will  be  selected from the  prioritized  list.  The  project  is  the 
first phase of implementation of the program and includes five priority national roads identified 
by the DOW.6 It is envisaged that the scope of the project will be scaled up in future to include 
all  16 priority  roads  and  other  key  roads  by  financing  subsequent  phases  through  ADB’s 
Additional Financing Policy.7
 
The  Bailey  bridges  that  are  removed  from  the  national  roads  and  are  in  useable 
6. 
condition will be reassembled on selected rural roads that lack bridges for crossing streams and 
rivers. This will improve accessibility of the rural population to markets, livelihood opportunities, 
education, and health facilities. The improved connectivity of rural roads with the national roads 
will  enhance  the  effectiveness  of  the  overall  road  network,  bringing  higher  economic  returns 
from increased traffic.  
 
7. 
Road  safety  is  a  major  issue  in  PNG.  The  fatality  rate  of  45  road  deaths  per 
10,000 vehicles  in  PNG  is  one  of  the  highest  in the Western  Pacific  region.  About  37%  of  the 
deaths  are  pedestrians.  Rural  areas  have  a  much  higher  number  of  crashes,  fatalities,  and 
serious  injuries. The  National  Road  Safety  Council  (NRSC)  was  established  in  2007  to  advise 
and  coordinate  road  safety  activities.  Despite  limited  resources,  the  NRSC  has  been  actively 
pursuing road safety initiatives, particularly awareness campaigns, in and around the capital city 
of Port Moresby, which has the largest urban population. Similar initiatives are needed in rural 
areas, where 87% of the population resides and the accident rate is high.8
 
 
8. 
The  DOW’s  road  asset  management  system  was  established  in  2003  and  BAMS  was 
established  in  2005,  for  systematic  management  of  the  road  network.  The  DOW  relies  on 
provincial  staff to collect  and  update  the  database  regularly.  However,  because  of shortage of 
staff and financial resources, data collection has been irregular and fragmented. Over time, the 
database  has  become  outdated  and  is  of  little  use  for  planning  and  operations.  To  make 
effective use of BAMS, there is a need to improve the database.               
 
9. 
PNG’s  Strategic  Vision  2050;  the  Development  Strategic  Plan  (DSP),  2010–2030;  and 
the  Medium  Term  Development  Plan  (MTDP),  2011–2015  emphasize  lack  of  transport 
infrastructure  as  a  constraint  for  PNG’s  economic  and  social  development.  The  trade  and 
economic  development  targets  in  the  DSP  and  MTDP  require  considerable  growth  in  the 
coverage  and  quality  of  the  national  road  network.  The  10  economic  corridors  for  integrated 
development  in  the  DSP  coincide  with  the  16  priority  national  roads.  Improvements  on  these 
roads will have a direct impact on economic development. Effective service delivery and income 
opportunities  for  the  rural  population  are  key  priorities.  Improved  accessibility  of  rural  road 
networks will open up markets, increase agricultural profitability, facilitate market chain linkage 
with downstream processing and export markets, and increase access to education and health 
facilities.    
 
10. 
Development Plan, 2006–20109

The  bridge  replacement  program  is  included  in  the  current  National  Transport 
 but could not be implemented because of resource constraints. 

                                                
6 DOW has selected five priority corridors: Magi highway, Hiritano highway, Ramu highway, Sepik highway, and New 

Britain highway. 

7 ADB. 2010. Additional Financing: Enhancing Development Effectiveness. Manila.  
8 NRSC. 2011. 2007 Road Safety Data Report. Port Moresby.  
9 The National Transport Development Plan will remain effective until the government approves the new NTS. 

   

3 

A long-term National Transport Strategy (NTS), 2011–203010 is under preparation to support the 
DSP  and  will  become  effective  on  completion.  The  NTS  supports  the  bridge  replacement 
program  by  emphasizing  the  desirable  and/or minimum  level  of  service  for  the  national  roads, 
where narrow Bailey bridges are considered below standard and a safety and security risk. The 
government is keen to proceed with the replacement of temporary Bailey and other deteriorated 
bridges  on  the  national  roads  with  permanent  structures.  This  is  reflected  in  ADB’s  country 
partnership strategy, 2011–2015,11 and the country operations business plan, 2011–2012.12
 
B. 
 
11. 
The  impact  will  be  improved  access  to  markets  and  social  services  for  the  rural 
population  in  selected  provinces  of  PNG.  The  outcome  will  be  a  better  connected,  more 
efficient, and safer road network in rural areas of selected provinces.  
 
C. 
 
12. 
 

The project will have four key outputs:  

Impact and Outcome 

Outputs 

   

(i)  

(ii)  

Bridge  replacement.  The  project  will  replace  20–30  Bailey  bridges  on  five 
priority national roads (footnote 6) with permanent two-lane bridges. The bridges 
are  prioritized  for  each  road  following  detailed  selection  criteria  based  on 
(a) traffic,  (b)  condition,  (c)  residual  life,  (d)  availability  of  alternative  routes, 
(e) safety of road users, (f) population served, and (g) additional works involving 
major  realignment  and  river  training.  The  bridges  will  be  selected  considering 
priority  ranking,  availability  of  funds,  safeguards  and  economic  due  diligence 
requirements, and contract packaging.      
Improving  rural  access.  For  the  Bailey  bridges  that  have  been  removed  from 
the five priority national roads and are in usable condition, the project will finance 
their reassembly on rural roads that lack bridges. The provincial governments will 
identify priority rural roads, following selection guidelines, preferably in the vicinity 
of  the  location  from  where  the  bridges  were  removed.  The  dismantling, 
transportation,  and  reassembly  of  Bailey  bridges  will  be  part  of  the  main  civil 
works contract for construction of permanent bridges.       

(iii)   Capacity  development  of 

the  Department  of  Work’s  bridge  asset 
management  system. The project will support BAMS to engage and train staff, 
undertake inventory and condition surveys on the 16 priority national roads, and 
update  the  database  on  bridges.  The  work  will  be  carried  out  in  close 
coordination with the provincial units of the DOW.  

(iv)   Road  safety  awareness  in  rural  areas.  The  project  will  finance  road  safety 
campaigns in rural areas along the five priority national roads. The activities will 
include training for schoolchildren and communities in rural areas, complemented 
by media campaigns. The DOW will engage the NRSC under a contract to carry 
out road safety awareness in rural areas.  

 
D. 
 
13. 

Investment and Financing Plans  

The project is estimated to cost $100.0 million. The investment plan is in Table 1.

The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $40  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
14. 
resources  (OCR)  to  help  finance  the  project.  The  loan  will  have  a  25-year  term,  including  a 
grace  period  of  5  years,  an  annual  interest rate determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum 
(the interest and other charges during construction to be capitalized in the loan), and such other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The government has provided ADB 
with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based 
on  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own 
independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. The 
government has also requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR30,999,000 from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 32-year term, 
including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period 
and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan 
agreement.       
 
15. 
$10 million including local taxes and duties. The financing plan is in Table 2.

5 

Implementation Arrangements 

E. 
 
16. 
The  DOW  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  for  the  project.  The 
existing  project  implementation  unit  (PIU)  within  the  DOW  that  is  responsible  for  all  ADB-
financed  projects  will  implement  this  project.  The  PIU,  headed  by  the  project  director  for  ADB 
loans, will be strengthened with additional staff to manage day-to-day implementation activities. 
The  PIU  will  be  responsible  for  engaging  all  consulting  services  and  civil  works  contracts.  A 
project  steering  committee  (PSC)  will  oversee  implementation,  monitor  progress,  provide 
guidance  to  the  executing  agency,  and  approve  bridges  to  be  replaced  on  selected  priority 
national  roads  as  well  as  sites  on  rural  roads  where  reusable  Bailey  bridges  will  be 
reassembled. The PSC will meet at least quarterly and will be chaired by the secretary, DOW. 
The members of the PSC will comprise representatives from the National Roads Authority, the 
Department of Transport, the NRSC, the Department of National Planning and Monitoring, and 
the  Department  of  Treasury.  Representatives  of  the  Department  of  Environment  and 
Conservation, the Department of Lands and Physical Planning, and provincial governments may 
be invited to PSC meetings to discuss specific issues.   
 
17. 
The project will finance additional staff, equipment, and office furnishings to supplement 
the existing PIU resources for implementing the project. The additional staffing will consist of a 
project  engineer,  an  accountant,  and  a  community  development  officer 
to  oversee 
implementation  of  the  gender  action  and  resettlement  plans.  ADB  financing  for  PIU 
strengthening  is  an  integral  part  of  ADB’s  support  for  capacity  development.  The  government 
has  given  assurance  that  upon  completion  of  the  project,  the  additional  PIU  staff  will  be 
integrated into the DOW. 
 
The  project  will  be  implemented  over  5  years,  with  completion  by  December  2016.  To 
18. 
expedite

procurement action for the engagement of a project implementation support consultant who will 
be  responsible  for  detailed  design,  construction  supervision,  and  overall  implementation 
support.  ADB  has  informed  the  government  that  approval  of  advance  action  does  not  commit 
ADB to finance the project. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and 
described in detail in the project administration manual (PAM).13

Source: Asian Development Bank. 

 

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
19. 
A  number  of  major  bridges  on  all  five  priority  national  roads,  particularly  on  the  Ramu 
and New Britain highways, could not be considered under the project as their current location is 
not  suitable  because  of  changing  river  hydrology.  Detailed  hydrological  and  geotechnical  field 
investigations  are  needed  before  a  decision  can  be  taken  regarding  the  location  of  these 
bridges.  In  some  cases,  landslides  and  other  similar  phenomena  upstream  cause  major 
changes  in  the  river  flow,  requiring  more  innovative  bridge  designs.  Grant-financed  policy  and 
advisory TA is attached to the loans to undertake the studies and prepare recommendations for 
the  location  and  design  of  major  bridges.  The  recommendations  will  enable  the  inclusion  of 
major  bridges  in  future  phases.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $900,000.  ADB  will  finance 
$800,000  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The 
government  will  provide  $100,000  equivalent  to  finance  counterpart  staff,  office  facilities,  and 
other  expenditures.  The  DOW  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  the  TA  will  be  implemented 
from January to June 2013.  
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
20. 
The project will benefit the largely rural population of about 400,000 in the provinces of 
Central,  Madang,  East  Sepik,  and  West  and  East  New  Britain  along  the  five  priority  national 
roads. The economic analysis is based on analyzing cost and benefits streams with and without 
the  project  over  25  years  and  discounted  at  12%.  The  economic  analysis  was  undertaken  for 
27 high-ranked  bridges  on  the  selected  five  priority  roads.  The  quantified  benefits  include 
savings  of  vehicle  operating  costs  and  value  of  time  from  avoiding  traffic  slowdown  and 
congestion  on  existing  bridges,  and  disruption  following  the  failure  of  the  existing  bridges.  In 
addition, the analysis considers benefits from reduced maintenance costs and improved safety 
of the new two-lane permanent structures. The economic internal rate of return for the project is 
15.5% and the economic net present value is $20.3 million. Sensitivity analysis involving a 20% 
decrease  in  benefits  and  a  20%  increase  in  costs  shows  that  the  economic  internal  rate  of 
return  remains  close  to  12%.  The  use  of  old  Bailey  bridges  from  national  roads  to  improve 
access  on  rural  roads  will  result  in  benefits  to  rural  communities  that  cannot  be  quantified. 
Among others, these include increased access to economic activities and education and health 
facilities.         
 
21. 
Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.14

Financial  due  diligence  of  the  project  was  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
 The financial sustainability of the project was 

                                                
14  ADB. 2005. Financial Management and Analysis of Projects. Manila. The project is classified a nonrevenue project 

under ADB guidelines. 

   

7 

assessed at national and project levels. An analysis of projected expenditure was undertaken to 
evaluate the impact of the project on planned transport sector funding, including an assessment 
of  the  government’s  ability  to  absorb  the  investment  financing  and  determine  if  sufficient 
resource  planning  has  been  undertaken  to  sustain  project  activities.  While  the  government  is 
taking  a  number  of  steps  to  ensure  the  long-term  sustainability  of  infrastructure  projects,  the 
loan  agreement  will  include  assurances  for  counterpart  and  recurrent  funding  to  be  provided. 
This will ensure that the appropriate level of resources will be made available in the medium and 
long term to sustain project activities. 
 
22. 
To  ensure  the  long-term  sustainability  of  road  projects,  the  National  Roads  Authority 
(NRA) was established in 2003 to (i) raise funds for the maintenance of public roads; (ii) ensure 
the efficient preparation of effective annual road maintenance programs; and (iii) ensure that all 
road  maintenance  is  executed  in  a  transparent,  effective,  and  efficient  manner.  In  2009,  the 
NRA  had  revenue  of  K18.3  million,  primarily  raised  through  a  small  fuel  levy  on  diesel,  with 
about K67 million in reserves. Over 2,000 km of the national roads were transferred to the NRA, 
including significant sections of the five priority national roads included in the project. The NRA 
is maintaining some of the nominated sections but needs additional resources. To increase the 
NRA’s funding and ensure its long-term sustainability, work is ongoing to increase the fuel levy, 
and introduce additional license fee for heavy vehicles, and other road user charges.15
  
 
For road networks at provincial and district levels, the government provides a transport 
23. 
infrastructure  maintenance  grant  as  a  block  allocation  to  each  province.  The  government  is 
committed  to  increasing  the  grants  and  appropriated  K45  million  for  this  purpose  in  2010  to 
increase provinces’ fiscal capacity to meet their transport infrastructure maintenance expenses. 
 
B. 
 
24. 
The DOW has implemented several projects funded by development partners, including 
projects financed by ADB. A capacity assessment of the current PIU within the DOW concluded 
that  project management  arrangements  are reasonably  robust,  though  some strengthening for 
this project is recommended.  
 
Financial  control  procedures  for  the  PIU  follow  the  Department  of  Finance’s  financial 
25. 
management manual. No significant financial management issues have been raised in external 
audit reports, or in other reports used by the DOW and key stakeholders for monitoring existing 
PIU  projects.  The  financial  management  arrangements  in  place  at  the  PIU  will  continue  to  be 
followed for this project. The PSC will ensure coordination across all aspects of the project.  
 
26. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  DOW.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM.  

Governance 

 
Poverty and Social 

C. 
 
27. 
PNG  ranks  149  out  of  179  countries  in  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme’s 
Human  Development  Index.  With  87%  of  the  population  living  in  rural  areas,  the  poverty 
incidence is higher in rural than urban areas. Given the reliance on subsistence farming in most 
rural areas, the nature of rural poverty relates more to a lack of access to basic social services 
such  as  education  and  health  facilities,  and  lack  of  income-earning  opportunities,  rather  than 

                                                
15 ADB.  2010.  Consultancy  Services  for  the  Highlands  Region  Road  Improvement  Investment  Program,  Report  on 
Road User Charges. Manila; and ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Improving Road User 
Charges and Private Sector Participation in Road Development. Manila (TA 7420). 

 

 8 

 

Safeguards 

extreme hunger or destitution. Access to basic social services is especially constrained in rural 
areas  because  of  poor  infrastructure  coverage,  including  road  connectivity  and  transport 
services.  
 
The  project  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  socioeconomic  development  in  the 
28. 
project  areas  by  improving  the  access  of  the  rural  population  to  livelihood  opportunities  and 
basic  social  services,  reducing  their  travel  time,  and  making  these  essential  trips  safer.  The 
improved  accessibility  will  increase  the  economic  opportunities  of  poor  rural  households, 
promote school attendance among children, and improve health outcomes among women and 
children by facilitating access to health facilities.   
 
29. 
The  project  is  classified  “effective  gender  mainstreaming.”  Bridge  designs  will  take 
women’s  safety  concerns  in  road  travel  into  consideration,  and  relocation  of  usable  Bailey 
bridges will incorporate access to health facilities and schools into selection criteria. Women will 
be  engaged  in  semi-skilled  labor  for  construction  and  bridge  maintenance  activities  to  provide 
income-earning  opportunities.  The  road  safety  awareness  campaigns  will  address  personal 
safety concerns of women and children in road travel. A gender action plan has been prepared 
and  the  PIU  will  monitor  its  implementation,  supported  by  the  implementation  support 
consultant. They will collect and analyze sex-disaggregated data in monitoring project activities 
as well as the gender action plan.  
  
D. 
 
30. 
Environmental.  The  project  is  classified  category  B  according  to  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009).  An  environmental  assessment  review  framework  has  been  prepared 
that presents the general anticipated environmental impacts of the project, selection criteria, and 
environmental  procedures  for  undertaking  both  replacement  and  reassembly  of  bridges.  An 
initial  environmental  examination,  including  an  environmental  management  plan,  has  been 
prepared  for  the  five  selected  priority  roads.  The  DOW  has  formally  submitted  the  five  initial 
the 
environmental  examinations  and  environmental  assessment  review 
Department  of  Environment  and  Conservation  for  information.  Approval  is  not  required  under 
PNG law.  
 
The  construction  phase  impacts  will  be  temporary  and  primarily  related  to  increased 
31. 
water  turbidity  associated  with  pile-driving,  excavation,  and  river  training  works.  No  significant 
operational impacts are expected. Mitigating measures have been developed, focusing on good 
international  construction  practices.  With  appropriate  mitigation  measures,  environmental 
impacts associated with the project are expected to be minor, site-specific, and temporary. The 
implementation  support  consultant  team  will  include  an  environmental  specialist  who  will 
monitor  implementation  of  the  environmental  management  plan.  The  environmental  specialist 
will  also  provide  on-the-job  training  and  capacity  building  of  DOW  staff  in  the  areas  of 
environmental mitigation, environmental monitoring, and occupational health and safety.  
 
32. 
Climate  change  is  expected  to  have  implications  on  the  hydrologic  and  hydraulic 
properties  of  the  bridge  sites.  The  bridge  design  will  incorporate  climate  change  impacts, 
particularly  changes  in  the  frequency  and  intensity  of  floods.  The  ongoing  TA  will  help  in 
estimating present and future climatic conditions for bridge designs and for climate-proofing of 
the project.16
 

framework 

to 

   

                                                
16 A study of the climate change impacts on bridge design and recommendations for climate proofing of the bridges 
under the project is under way, financed through ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Promoting Climate Change 
Adaptation in Asia and the Pacific. Manila.  

   

9 

Social  safeguards.  The  project  has  been  classified  category  B  for  involuntary 
33. 
resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples.  It  is  not  expected  to  involve  physical  displacement  of 
people. It will, however, require acquisition of land for replacement of some bridges, resulting in 
loss of crops and trees on that land, and relocation of roadside food markets at some locations. 
Resettlement  plans  have  been  prepared  for  each  of  the  five  selected  priority  national  roads 
included  in  the  project,  based  on  the  assessment  of  impacts  and  consultations  with  affected 
landowners.  The  resettlement  plans  include  measures  to  compensate  for  affected  land  and 
assets,  and  to  assist  affected  persons  to  restore  and  improve  their  livelihoods.  A  resettlement 
framework has been prepared, providing guidelines on screening, assessment, and preparation 
of resettlement plans, if needed, for replacement of bridges on national roads and reassembly of 
Bailey bridges on rural roads that will be selected during implementation. Affected landowners 
and  local  stakeholders  have  been  consulted  and  provided  relevant  information  during 
preparation of the resettlement plans. The DOW has endorsed the resettlement framework and 
resettlement plans that have been disclosed locally and posted on the ADB website.     
 
34. 
A  social  assessment  concluded  that  ethnic  groups  in  the  project  area  are  primary 
beneficiaries  of  the  project  and  not  distinct  or  vulnerable  compared  to  PNG’s  mainstream 
population,  which  is  mostly  made  up  of  Melanesians.  The  leaders  of  local  communities/clans 
from  potential  project  sites  have  expressed  support for  the  project. The  overall  project  design, 
particularly  the  resettlement  framework  and  resettlement  plans,  ensure  that  they  receive 
culturally appropriate benefits and actively participate in the project activities.  
 
35. 
The  DOW  and  provincial  governments  will  assign  lands  officers  to  manage  land 
acquisition and resettlement activities. The implementation support consultant team will include 
an international resettlement specialist and a national resettlement specialist to assist the DOW 
and  provincial  governments  to  manage  social  safeguard  aspects.  The  consultant  team  will 
provide  necessary  safeguard  training  to  relevant  government  staff  involved  in  land  acquisition 
and resettlement.

in the risk assessment and risk management plan.17
